title: Default Warnings Start to Pile Up in Private Credit Market - Yahoo Finance
summary:
Warnings on defaults are starting to pile up in the $1.7 trillion private credit market, prompting at least some analysts to raise concern about underappreciated risks in one of Wall Street’s favorite money spinners.
While there is no universal definition of what constitutes default in private credit, default rates for the market are currently in the 2% to 3% range.
The adjustment puts the default rate for private credit broadly in line with that observed in the broadly syndicated loan market.
Returns above 8% are still luring investment, although private credit funds are not the cash magnet they once were.
“A major selling point of private credit is the low default rates,” Bukhari wrote in a report this month.

title: Credit Fuels the AI Boom — and Fears of a Bubble - Yahoo Finance
summary:
Credit investors are pouring billions of dollars into artificial intelligence investments, just as industry executives and analysts are raising questions about whether the new technology is inflating another bubble.
OpenAI alone estimates it will need trillions of dollars over time to spend on the infrastructure required to develop and run artificial intelligence services.
At the same time, key players in the industry acknowledge there is probably pain ahead for AI investors.
OpenAI Chief Executive Officer Sam Altman said this week that he sees parallels between the current investment frenzy in artificial intelligence and the dot-com bubble in the late 1990s.
Recently, though, the money has been increasingly coming from bond investors and private credit lenders.

title: Tokenized Equities In The Crosshairs Of Global Stock Exchanges: What Happened? - Coinbase Global (NASDAQ:COIN) - Benzinga
summary:
The World Federation of Exchanges (WFE), which represents leading global stock exchanges and clearing houses, has urged regulators to tighten oversight of tokenized equities, warning that the blockchain-based products could mislead investors and undermine market integrity.
Tokenized equities are digital tokens issued on blockchains that represent exposure to a company's stock but do not grant actual ownership or voting rights.
Despite claims of cheaper transactions, faster settlement, and 24/7 accessibility, the WFE said the products risk confusing investors.
A U.S. SEC commissioner stated in July that tokenized securities must comply with existing rules.
Coinbase COIN is also seeking approval from the SEC to roll out tokenized equities in the U.S., Reuters previously reported.

summary:

How Investors Should Navigate the Private Credit Minefield Unlike traditional banks, private credit funds operate largely outside the rigorous oversight that governs deposit-taking institutions.
Consider strengthening cash flows, limiting nonessential expenditures, and securing backup credit facilities if concerns about a private credit market squeeze increase.
The Bottom Line The private credit industry's explosive growth to $2 trillion represents both opportunity and significant risk.
Jamie Dimon's warnings suggest that private credit could face a reckoning, and the question is whether the broader economy is prepared for the fallout.

title: BlackRock's $1B Asia Credit Fund Hits Pause Amid HPS Deal and Rising Market Risks - Yahoo Finance
summary:
BlackRock Inc. (NYSE:BLK) has hit pause on fundraising for its third Asia-Pacific private credit fund after announcing the acquisition of HPS Investment Partners in December, with the deal officially closing on July 1.
The $1 billion fund, launched in late 2023, had secured less than half of its target before the pause as internal discussions with HPS executives continue on how to align strategy going forward.
The pause comes against a more challenging backdrop for the $1.7 trillion global private credit market.
That puts private credit defaults broadly in line with the syndicated loan market and has raised concerns among some investors about potential risks that may not yet be fully priced in.
The firm recently ended its private credit partnership with Abu Dhabi's Mubadala Investment Co. after facing difficulties sourcing deals, underscoring ongoing headwinds in the region.

title: MetLife Investment Management Names Geert Henckens Global Head of Private Fixed Income - Morningstar
summary:
MetLife Investment Management (MIM), the institutional asset management business of MetLife, Inc. (NYSE: MET), today announced that it has named Geert Henckens global head of Private Fixed Income.
MIM has a longstanding track record of originating and managing private assets and originated $21.6 billion in private fixed income transactions in 2024.
MIM’s total private fixed income assets under management stood at $154.8 billion as of June 30, 2025.1 “As a premier originator of private assets, MIM’s private fixed income platform is a key differentiator in capturing current and emerging trends, such as the rise of non-bank lending,” said Brian Funk, president of MIM.
“Our private fixed income platform is well positioned with deep capabilities in originating and managing private assets for our clients, from traditional high-grade private debt, including corporate and infrastructure debt, to private asset-based finance, residential credit and private equity and middle market direct lending.” About MetLife Investment Management MetLife Investment Management, the institutional asset management business of MetLife, Inc. (NYSE: MET), provides tailored investment management solutions to institutional investors worldwide.
MetLife Investment Management has over 150 years of investment experience and, as of June 30, 2025, had $624.3 billion in total assets under management.

title: How Private Equity Funds Understate the Risk in Their Investments - Morningstar
summary:
Volatility laundering, a term coined by AQR’s Cliff Asness, describes how private equity funds systematically understate the actual risk in their investments.
Private equity holdings are typically valued only quarterly, and these valuations often rely on models and assumptions rather than real-time market pricing.
Note that this should not be interpreted to mean that private equity is one-third as risky as public equity, but the multiples have been 3 times as volatile.
This doesn’t necessarily make private equity (or private credit or private real estate) a poor investment choice.
However, it does mean investors relying on smoothed return data are likely underestimating their risk exposure (more so in private equity than in private credit).

title: Singapore Bank DBS Debuts Tokenized Structured Notes on Ethereum - Yahoo Finance
summary:
Singaporean bank DBS will tokenize structured notes using Ethereum, the company announced Thursday.
DBS told Decrypt that the first tokenized structured note will be linked to the performance of Bitcoin.
Structured notes blend debt securities and derivatives contracts to provide investors with exposure to a range of assets, including stocks and commodities.
"Asset tokenisation is the next frontier of financial markets infrastructure," DBS' Head of Foreign Exchange and Digital Assets, Global Financial Markets, Li Zhen, said.
"Our first tokenised product, a crypto-linked note, also addresses the growing institutional appetite for digital assets," he added.

title: Kraken Meets SEC Crypto Task Force to Discuss Asset Tokenization - Yahoo Finance
summary:
Key Takeaways: Kraken met with the SEC to discuss regulatory frameworks for its tokenized trading system.
Regulators are pressing for stricter oversight of tokenized stocks, citing weak investor protections.
Unlike conventional equities, tokenized stocks can be traded around the clock and often fall outside the same disclosure and reporting rules.
Kraken announced its tokenized stock service on May 22, allowing non-U.S. investors to trade U.S. equities 24/7.

summary:

title: What Investors Should Know About Investing in Private Debt - Investopedia
summary:
Also known as private credit, private debt refers to a type of financing in which a non-bank creditor lends to a private entity, such as a company or a project.
Benefits of Private Debt For many investors, the primary appeal of private debt is its potential to provide stronger returns than traditional fixed-income investments.
Risks of Private Debt Private debt may offer the potential for higher yields, but it also has an inherent risk of default.
Speaking of which, the three main avenues for investing in private debt include: Private credit funds: These specialized investment vehicles pool funds from investors that their managers can lend to private entities or use to buy existing private loans.
Where Private Debt Fits in a Portfolio Private debt can be a valuable addition to a diversified portfolio, especially as a complement to your fixed income strategy.

title: What Investors Should Know About Private Debt, Real Estate, and Other Private Market Assets - Investopedia
summary:
Private market assets—such as private debt, real estate, and infrastructure—are attracting more attention from investors seeking alternatives to traditional stocks and bonds.
Understanding Private Market Assets Private market assets are investments in companies or projects not traded on public stock exchanges.
Private debt: Similar to a loan, private debt gives companies access to funding without using public markets.
Real assets: Tangible assets like real estate, infrastructure (such as highways, airports, or energy grids), and natural resources.
Here's a closer look at each: Private Real Estate Private real estate involves direct investment in physical properties, including residential homes, commercial office buildings, and industrial facilities like warehouses and distribution centers.
